en.value: imagine
Expressing approval and disagreement
I stopped eating meat because I thought I would be healthier.
I cleaned the whole house, then I made dinner. I really wanted a new coat, so I went shopping.
We stayed in all weekend [k]because[/k] we didn't have enough money to go out.
I suspect that he's lying but I can't be sure.
There's something strange about him, do you know what I mean?
Police officer
Yes I saw it on the news. He did [k]admit[/k] that the government needs to do more though.
Yes, I understand. I hope you find the people that did it.
We use because to give the reason for something happening.
disagree
She was opposed to the death penalty.
[k]I got to work late[/k] [k]so[/k] [k]I had to stay[/k] [k]late  in the evening.[/k]
Benjamin
suspect
Is that correct?
Express yourself
[k]We went to France[/k] [k]because[/k] [k]my parents[/k] [k]live there.[/k]
Your address is 12 London Road, is that correct?
admit
Did you see the Prime Minister being interviewed yesterday? He didn't [k]acknowledge[/k] any of the points that the interviewer made.
Is that clear?
I'm not sure that I follow... could you explain that again, please?
I like her because she makes me laugh.
I [k]agree[/k] with you. I'm [k]opposed to[/k] the plans.
I cleaned the whole house, then I made dinner.
I prepared the dinner earlier so I have more time tonight.
agree
[k]I love you,[/k] [k]but[/k] [k]you cause me[/k] [k]lots of problems.[/k]
But
opposed to
I decided to leave my job after arguing with my boss. After arguing with my boss I decided to leave my job. The book is meant for children although lots of adults read it.
We often use connecting words to connect two clauses in a sentence. Different connecting words show different relationships between the clauses.
Select the words in the correct order.
Laura
although and after can be placed at the beginning of the sentence or between the two clauses. then and but are usually placed between the two clauses.
So what do you think about the government's new plans?
Are you saying that...
Why don't you get on well with your brother?
Do you understand?
I really wanted a new coat, so I went shopping.
Are you with me?
[k]I decided[/k] [k]to leave my job[/k] [k]after[/k] [k]arguing[/k] [k]with my boss.[/k]
[k]Because[/k] [k]the traffic was bad[/k] [k]we decided[/k] [k]to walk to the party.[/k]
I know it's a lot to take in. Have I explained it clearly?
[k]Are you saying that[/k] my car isn't outside my house? [k]I'm not sure that I follow[/k], officer.
Hello Mrs Smith. I'm a police officer. I'm calling about your car.
Are you saying that I'll have to do it on my own?
I recognise the need for change.

I imagine that I would be exhausted if I worked 65 hours per week. I suspect that people would be less productive if they worked more hours. In fact, some argue that working fewer hours would help employees to focus better.
She admits that she made a mistake.
I felt very sad [k]after[/k] I got the bad news.
[k]Although[/k] the course is only two weeks long, it's very hard work.
Grammar: Connecting words
[k]She arrived at 12,[/k] [k]then[/k] [k]she left[/k] [k]an hour later.[/k]
Although the team played well, they didn't win the competition.
You must stop behaving like this, is that clear?
So, does what I just said make sense?
I'm afraid that your car was reported stolen this morning at 10 o'clock. A neighbour saw the thieves driving away.
recognise
After dinner I went out for a run.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Select the correct option.
Does that make sense?
Have I explained that clearly?
The sentence shows the order that events happened.
Emma
The exam started and then I realised I didn't know anything.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I completely agree with you.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
I don't understand what you mean.
I've never been to Italy but I imagine it's a beautiful country.
I hurt my leg, [k]so[/k] I couldn't do any of the activities.
Do you understand?
acknowledge
doubt
I went to the shop (1st thing) then made dinner. (2nd thing)
He didn't acknowledge any of my points. He just continued arguing.
I really enjoy working there, but I don't get paid enough. Although the team played well, they didn't win the competition.
because can be used between the two clauses, or at the start of the sentence. so is usually between the two clauses when used as a connecting word.
I disagree with the second point that you made.
in favour of
I really enjoy working there, but I don't get paid enough.
We can use after and then to talk about the order in which things happened.
I enjoyed the skiing, [k]but[/k] I wasn't very good at it.
The sentence shows a contrast between two clauses.
We'll have to call your parents, Edward. Do you understand?
I don't understand what you mean... could you go over it again?
I'm having a lot of back problems.
The sentence shows cause an effect between two clauses.
We can use but and although to show a contrast between two clauses. 'Although' can be used at the beginning of the sentence, or between the two clauses. 'but' is usually used between the two clauses.
My friend is lovely, but he doesn't talk very much.
I doubt we'll get there before 10 o'clock.

Unfortunately the car registered to your address has been stolen. You'll have to come to the police station as soon as you get back from your holiday so we can go through the details. [k]Is that clear[/k]?
I'm not sure that I follow
Yes, I definitely have some questions for him!
although
We went to France because my parents live there. Because the traffic was bad we decided to walk to the party. I got to work late so I had to stay late in the evening.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Oh dear. What's the problem? I'm actually on holiday at the moment.

The sentence contains connecting words to join two different clauses.
[k]Although[/k] [k]it looks good,[/k] [k]the food[/k] [k]tastes terrible.[/k]
so
We wanted to live here forever, so we bought a house.
OK. But let me just confirm something. You live in Baker street, [k]is that correct[/k]?
Firstly,  mix the eggs and the flour, and then add the milk.
I [k]imagine[/k] that people will be asking lots more questions over the next few weeks.
I strongly [k]disagree[/k] with them. I think it's a ridiculous proposal. What about you?
We often use so to introduce the result of an action or situation.
I went to the shops because I needed milk.
Yes that's right. Is everything OK?
True or false?
but
[k]The book is meant[/k] [k]for children,[/k] [k]although[/k] [k]lots of adults[/k] [k]read it.[/k]
Do you think people should be obliged to work 65 hours a week?
I am in favour of the plans to build a new school.
I felt a pain in my knees and [k]then[/k] I knew I had a problem.
That's true but they still need to [k]recognise[/k] what the public really want.
